channel.title: R Markdown on It works
channel.description: Recent content in R Markdown on It works

item.title: Star Wars Baby Names Sad Plot 2.0
item.description: Babynames Sad Graph This graph was pretty much my first time graphing something in ggplot2! I would like to polish it up by: Adding a few more names to it to make it a little more interesting (Luke, Han, Lando…). I’d like to change it to a density plot (I think?) to make it a little cooler looking. Because these names are probably a fairly small proportion of the total babynames, I’d like to do something to adjst the scale so it’s easier to see.

item.title: Waco Home Prices Sad Plot 2.0
item.description: 1) Clean Reproducible Code knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE) library(dplyr) ## ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2) library(tidyverse) ## -- Attaching packages -------------------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.2.1 -- ## v tibble 1.4.2 v purrr 0.2.5 ## v tidyr 0.8.1 v stringr 1.3.1 ## v readr 1.1.1 v forcats 0.3.0 ## -- Conflicts ----------------------------------------------------- tidyverse_conflicts() -- ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() library(ggthemes) library(plotly) ## ## Attaching package: 'plotly' ## The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2': ## ## last_plot ## The following object is masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter ## The following object is masked from 'package:graphics': ## ## layout library(RColorBrewer) waco <- txhousing %>% filter(city == "Waco", year >= 2004) %>% group_by(year) %>% mutate(median_waco = median(median), gt_median = median >= median_waco) waco_homes <- ggplot(waco, aes(x = year, y = median, color = gt_median)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.

item.title: Sad Plot #1 Star Wars Baby Names
item.description: 1) Clean Reproducible Code star_wars <- babynames %>% filter(name == "Leah" | name == "Leia") %>% filter(sex == "F") %>% filter(year >= 1975) ## Warning: package 'bindrcpp' was built under R version 3.4.4 plot <- ggplot(star_wars, aes(x = year, y = prop, group = name, color = name)) + geom_line(size = 2) + geom_vline(xintercept = 1977, linetype="dashed", color = "blue", size=1) + geom_vline(xintercept = 1999, linetype="dashed", color = "blue", size=1) + geom_vline(xintercept = 2014, linetype="dashed", color = "blue", size=1) + annotate("text", x = 1980, y = 0.

item.title: This is a new post
item.description: Is this how you add in stuff? 1 + 1 ## [1] 2 rnorm(10) # 10 random numbers ## [1] -0.4324180 0.2561106 0.0100047 0.9054032 0.0193092 -0.9927873 ## [7] -0.3972822 -2.6278047 -2.0962900 -1.3466407 plot(dist ~ speed, cars) # a scatterplot This is another test at how to add in stuff library(babynames) ## Warning: package 'babynames' was built under R version 3.4.4 library(dplyr) ## Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 3.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
